issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for SealSaloon: the problem statement (UML and prose) requires a constructor SealSaloon(String) that accepts a saloon name, but both the provided example code in the template Main and the solution implementation use a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()). This contradiction (problem description vs. example/template/solution) will confuse students about which constructor to implement and whether a saloon name field is required/stored.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor requirement consistent across artifacts. Either: (A) Update the problem statement to require a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()) and remove the text saying the constructor takes a saloon name; or (B) change the template and solution to provide/expect a constructor SealSaloon(String name) (store the name in a private field and add a getter). Option B could also provide a no-arg overload that delegates to the named constructor to preserve the example in Main.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies a SealSaloon constructor that takes a String parameter (SealSaloon(String) — the saloon name) and asks that fields be initialized in the constructor. However, both the provided template usage (Main.java) and the solution implement and/or instantiate SealSaloon with a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()). This mismatch between the required constructor signature in the problem description and the actual no-arg constructor in code can confuse students about which constructor to implement and whether a saloon-name field is required.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor requirement consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution and template to provide a constructor SealSaloon(String name), add a private final String name field initialized in that constructor, and a corresponding getter (getName()), matching the UML/text; or (B) update the problem statement (UML and descriptive text) to require a no-argument constructor (SealSaloon()) so the description matches the template and solution. Option A is recommended if the saloon name is part of the exercise intent.
